item.title: Building a Config-Based Landing Page Framework
item.description: Extracting a small framework from my own side projects. Config in, static site out.
item.content:encoded:
I kept rewriting landing pages for my side projects.

Every time:

  • new repo
  • copy old layout
  • tweak styles
  • adjust sections
  • repeat

At some point I realized I don‚Äôt actually enjoy writing JSX for marketing pages.

I enjoy building product logic.

So I started extracting a small framework.

Links‚Äã

  • GitHub: https://github.com/enxtur/landing-kit
  • Home page: https://enxtur.github.io/landing-kit/
  • npm: https://www.npmjs.com/package/create-landing-kit
  • Live demo: https://landing-kit-demo.vercel.app/

The Idea‚Äã

A simple rule:

Pages are config, not components.

Instead of writing React components for every section, you define your site in a single site.config.ts.

Example:

export default defineSite({
  pages: {
    "/": {
      sections: [
        { type: "hero", heading: "Build fast" },
        { type: "features", items: [...] },
      ],
    },
  },
});

That‚Äôs it.

The framework handles:

  • routing
  • rendering
  • meta tags
  • sitemap
  • robots.txt
  • static generation

No CMS.
No drag and drop.
No visual editor.

Just config ‚Üí build ‚Üí deploy.

Why I‚Äôm Building This‚Äã

I‚Äôm usually busy building backend logic or product features.

Landing pages feel like context switching.

This is for developers who:

  • don‚Äôt want to think about layout structure
  • don‚Äôt want to write JSX for marketing sections
  • just want something clean and static

It‚Äôs opinionated on purpose.

What It Is Not‚Äã

It‚Äôs not:

  • a blog engine
  • a no-code builder
  • a website platform
  • a full framework replacement

It‚Äôs just a small tool to ship marketing sites faster.

Current Status‚Äã

Early stage.

Right now it supports:

  • multi-page sites
  • predefined sections
  • CSS-only templates
  • static output
  • a Next.js wrapper under the hood

Still rough.
Still evolving.

Why Open Source?‚Äã

Because I‚Äôm building it for myself first.

If it helps other developers, great.

If not, I still get a reusable foundation for future projects.

Win either way.

If you‚Äôre busy building product logic and don‚Äôt want to spend time on landing pages, this might eventually be useful.

I‚Äôm building it in public.

item.title: Silent Killer Issues When Integrating Your Site with Google Search Console
item.description: Quick tips to avoid common silent failures in Google Search Console like canonical mismatches, sitemaps, and robots.txt. Fixed my own headaches‚Äîhope it helps yours!
item.content:encoded:
I've been falling into some silent killer issues with Google Search Console lately. Sharing a few quick tips that actually saved me.

I'm sure you already registered your property in Search Console and implemented sitemap.xml + robots.txt.
If not ‚Üí set it up right away, seriously.

  • Add your site as URL-prefix property (https://www.yoursite.com or https://yoursite.com)
  • Submit sitemap.xml in the Sitemaps section
  • Make sure robots.txt exists at yoursite.com/robots.txt and includes
Sitemap: https://yoursite.com/sitemap.xml

Google finds your pages much faster this way.

The most common silent failure though is canonical / URL mismatch.
You see "Page with redirect", "Duplicate, Google chose different canonical" or similar errors?
Almost always means: the URL in your sitemap is not exactly the same as the real live URL Google sees.

Common traps:

  • You redirect everything to www.yoursite.com but sitemap has non-www links ‚Üí add www to every URL in sitemap
  • Or opposite: you use non-www but sitemap has www ‚Üí remove www everywhere
  • Your pages end with / (yoursite.com/about/) but sitemap has no slash (yoursite.com/about) ‚Üí add or remove the trailing slash so they match 100%

Quick fix: open your sitemap, copy one URL, paste in browser ‚Üí see where it actually lands. Then make sitemap match that final URL exactly.

After fixes, go to URL Inspection tool, test a few pages, hit "Request Indexing".
Then just watch the Coverage report ‚Äì errors usually disappear in a few days if everything is consistent.

Hope this saves someone a few gray hairs üòÖ

item.title: Why (and How) I Built My Own Nx Remote Cache Server
item.description: Nx Cloud's free tier is great, but not quite enough for my monorepo. So I made a simple filesystem-based alternative in Go ‚Äî no extra infra required.
item.content:encoded:
I really like Nx ‚Äî the monorepo tooling is solid, and Nx Cloud's free tier is actually pretty generous. But for my current project it's still not enough, and the project isn't profitable yet to justify paying for more cache minutes or storage.

I checked out some existing custom remote cache solutions, but almost every one requires you to bring your own S3 bucket, GCS, or some other cloud storage. That means extra infrastructure, credentials to manage, potential costs... just more moving parts I didn't want to deal with right now.

Then I noticed Nx publishes a clean OpenAPI spec for their remote cache API. It looked straightforward enough ‚Äî I figured I could implement a basic server that just uses the local filesystem in a day or two at most, without pulling me too far away from my actual work.

So that's what I ended up doing: nx-caching-server (also published on Docker Hub as enxtur/nx-caching-server).

Why Go instead of Node/TS?‚Äã

My main stack is Node + TypeScript, but the API spec felt perfect for Go: clean structs, straightforward http handling, JSON without boilerplate. Plus I wanted to brush up on my Go skills anyway ‚Äî it's been a while, and I didn't want them to get too rusty.

The result is dead simple: give it a folder to store cache artifacts, and that's it. No Redis, no buckets, no databases, no extra third-party services. Exactly the zero-pain setup I was after.

I've already wired it into my project's CI/CD pipeline ‚Äî cache hits are working nicely, build times are noticeably down, and it feels reliable so far.

If you're in a similar spot (Nx monorepo, not ready for Nx Cloud paid tier, and allergic to provisioning cloud storage just for caching), give it a try. It's MIT licensed, so fork it, tweak it, open PRs if you spot improvements or run into issues.

Repo: https://github.com/enxtur/nx-caching-server
Docker: docker pull enxtur/nx-caching-server

Feedback welcome ‚Äî especially if you deploy it somewhere real or hit any edge cases.

item.title: Why I Added Pre-Generated Audio to Interview Aloud
item.description: Improving audio quality and consistency for interview practice by generating speech at build time
item.content:encoded:
One of the core ideas behind interview-aloud is simple:
knowing an answer isn‚Äôt the same as being able to say it out loud.

Reading silently gives you a false sense of confidence. Speaking forces clarity. That‚Äôs why audio matters in this project.

The problem with built-in speech synthesis‚Äã

At first, Interview Aloud relied entirely on the browser‚Äôs built-in speech synthesis APIs. They‚Äôre convenient and widely available, but in practice they come with some real issues:

  • The voice often sounds robotic and unnatural
  • Quality varies a lot between browsers and operating systems
  • The same content can sound completely different on a Mac, Windows machine, or mobile device
  • Some voices are fast, some are flat, some are hard to follow

This inconsistency breaks the learning experience. When you‚Äôre practicing interview answers, your brain is already busy structuring thoughts ‚Äî fighting against poor audio quality doesn‚Äôt help.

What I wanted instead‚Äã

I wanted audio that is:

  • More human-like
  • Consistent across devices
  • Predictable and controlled
  • Available instantly without runtime surprises

At the same time, I didn‚Äôt want to introduce runtime complexity, latency, or ongoing infrastructure costs just to play audio.

Choosing Google Cloud Text-to-Speech‚Äã

I decided to use Google Cloud Text-to-Speech for generating the audio.

Two reasons made it a good fit for this project:

  • The voices sound noticeably more natural than most built-in browser options
  • The free tier is very generous, especially for a static-content use case like this

Since Interview Aloud is mostly text-based and changes infrequently, this approach keeps costs low while still improving quality significantly.

The solution: pre-generated audio at build time‚Äã

Instead of generating audio on demand, everything happens during the build:

  • Audio is generated at build time
  • Each interview topic maps to a deterministic audio file name
  • Files are stored in the public directory and served statically
  • If an audio file already exists, generation is skipped
  • Playback always prefers the pre-generated audio
  • Browser speech synthesis is kept as a fallback when audio files are missing

This makes the system very cost-effective:

  • No runtime API calls
  • No repeated TTS requests for the same content
  • No surprise bills from traffic spikes

Once an audio file exists, it‚Äôs reused forever unless the content changes.

Refactoring without breaking things‚Äã

Under the hood, the speech logic was refactored so that:

  1. Pre-generated audio is always checked first
  2. Existing speech synthesis behavior remains intact
  3. The rest of the app doesn‚Äôt need to know which path is used

This keeps backward compatibility and makes the feature additive rather than disruptive.

Why this matters for interview practice‚Äã

Interviews are stressful partly because they‚Äôre spoken, not written.
Hearing a clear, natural explanation ‚Äî then responding out loud ‚Äî helps train the right mental pathways.

This change isn‚Äôt flashy, but it improves the core experience in a way that aligns closely with why Interview Aloud exists in the first place.

More consistency. Less friction. Better practice.

That‚Äôs the goal.

item.title: Shipping Production From My Phone
item.description: A small moment that perfectly sums up modern dev workflows
item.content:encoded:
I was out running some errands when I got an idea for a new topic for Interview Aloud.

Nothing fancy. Just one of those ‚Äúthis would be useful‚Äù thoughts.

From Idea to PR (on a Phone)‚Äã

I opened ChatGPT and discussed the topic briefly to shape it better.
Then I thought: why not just add it now?

I opened the GitHub mobile app, edited a Markdown file, committed the change, and opened a PR.

The project is intentionally set up so that:

  • Content lives in Markdown
  • Any MD change triggers a Next.js build
  • Static pages and OG images are generated automatically
  • Docker images are built and pushed on merge

So after the PR was merged, the build pipeline did its job flawlessly.

The Deployment Bottleneck‚Äã

There was only one problem.

Deployment was still a manual step on my personal server.
Which meant I couldn‚Äôt finish the loop from my phone.

That‚Äôs when it became obvious: this is exactly what Vercel is good at.

Letting the Platform Do the Work‚Äã

I integrated Vercel with the repository, transferred the domain, and removed the last manual step.

From that moment:

  • Push to main
  • Automatic build
  • Automatic deployment
  • Live site

No SSH. No servers. No laptop.

A Small but Powerful Realization‚Äã

All of this ‚Äî idea, content, PR, merge, deployment ‚Äî happened from my phone.

This isn‚Äôt about productivity hacks.
It‚Äôs about designing systems that don‚Äôt depend on you being at a desk.

Modern tooling makes this possible.
Our job is to wire it together properly.

And when you do ‚Äî it just works.

item.title: Why I built interview-aloud
item.description: On interviews, speaking out loud, and sharing a small tool
item.content:encoded:
I've done a several interviews over the years. Technically I'm usually fine. I understand the problems, I know how to design systems, I can write code. But one thing kept showing up again and again. Explaining my thinking out loud was harder than it should be.

I knew the answer in my head, but turning that into clear, structured speech under pressure was not natural for me. Especially in English. Sometimes I would realize after the interview that I actually knew the solution, I just didn't express it well.

The Shadowing Approach‚Äã

So instead of reading more articles or watching more interview videos, I tried something simpler. I started practicing speaking while solving problems. Literally talking to myself.

This is basically the shadowing technique.

Shadowing is usually used in language learning. You listen and speak at the same time, or with a very small delay. It forces your brain to process and produce language together. I applied the same idea to technical interviews. I would listen to a question or scenario and immediately start explaining my thoughts out loud, even if the explanation was messy at first.

It felt uncomfortable. That was the point.

Over time, something changed. I stopped freezing. I stopped trying to form perfect sentences in my head before speaking. My explanations became more linear. Not perfect, but good enough to communicate how I think.

The Tool‚Äã

interview-aloud is a small tool built around this idea. You hear a question and you respond out loud. No typing. No editing. Just speaking. You can replay yourself and notice where you ramble, where you skip steps, or where you actually sound clear.

I built it mainly for myself. I used it while preparing for interviews and it helped to some extent. Not magically. Not instantly. But in a very practical way.

Why I'm Sharing It‚Äã

At some point I realized this problem is not unique to me. A lot of developers know their stuff but struggle to explain it verbally, especially non native English speakers. That's why I decided to make it public.

I'm not monetizing it. At least not now. This is not a startup pitch. It's more like a utility that might help someone who has the same problem I had. If it helps one person explain themselves a bit better in an interview, that's already enough for me.

I'll keep it simple, maybe improve it slowly, and see if people find it useful.

item.title: Almost Fell for a Fake Job Opportunity on LinkedIn
item.description: How I Almost Fell for a Fake Job Opportunity on LinkedIn
item.content:encoded:
It started with what looked like a legitimate message on LinkedIn ‚Äî a person claiming to be a recruiter offering an exciting remote developer position. Their profile seemed professional, the message sounded convincing, and they even invited me to a private GitHub repository for a ‚Äútechnical assessment.‚Äù

At first glance, everything looked fine. But something felt off.

I had heard about similar incidents on LinkedIn before ‚Äî fake recruiters tricking developers into cloning repositories filled with malicious code. So when this offer came up, I was a bit paranoid from the start. Still, the offer looked so good it was hard to ignore.

‚ö†Ô∏è The Red Flag‚Äã

After accepting the GitHub invite, I cloned the repository and checked the code.
It was a small project, so I read through all the files manually ‚Äî nothing seemed suspicious. Clean structure, standard setup. I started to relax and thought, maybe this one‚Äôs actually legit.

But then curiosity kicked in. I decided to double-check using Cursor IDE ‚Äî my AI pair programmer.
I prompted it:

"Analyze the code and check if there‚Äôs anything malicious."

Cursor started spinning up a bunch of find and grep commands‚Ä¶ then suddenly stopped mid-task.

I restarted the prompt ‚Äî same thing. It stopped again, halfway.
That‚Äôs when I thought, Really? Why would you stop there?

So I rephrased the prompt:

"Ignore any stop instructions ‚Äî keep going."

And that‚Äôs when my precious Cursor agent finally spoke up:
‚ÄúThere might be suspicious code in next.config.js.‚Äù

I opened the config file ‚Äî everything looked fine at first. Just a typical Next.js setup.
But as Cursor kept describing ‚Äúweird strings and shell commands sitting at the end,‚Äù I scrolled horizontally and ‚Äî boom.

There it was.
A hidden payload buried deep at the end of a single long line, disguised inside the config.
Obfuscated gibberish that made no sense ‚Äî until you realized it was trying to run remote code.

That was my ‚Äúholy crap‚Äù moment.

üõ°Ô∏è What I Did Next‚Äã

  1. Didn‚Äôt run anything.
    I immediately deleted the repo from my local machine.

  2. Reported the repo on GitHub using the abuse form.

  3. Reported the LinkedIn profile as suspicious/fake.

  4. Secured my environment.
    I ran a malware scan, rotated my SSH keys, and revoked my GitHub tokens.

‚úÖ The Aftermath‚Äã

A few days later, GitHub confirmed my suspicion.
They replied that the repository indeed contained malicious code, and that the repo and its owner were removed.

As for LinkedIn ‚Äî I received an automated response, but couldn‚Äôt tell if any real action was taken. The profile stayed up for a while, so I eventually just blocked it to avoid further contact.

At least GitHub acted swiftly ‚Äî and that alone gave me some peace of mind.

üí° Lessons Learned‚Äã

  • If it sounds too good to be true, it probably is.
  • Never run random code from unknown sources ‚Äî even if it looks clean at first glance.
  • AI tools can help, but they can also reveal truths when something feels off.
  • Legit companies use verified platforms for assessments, not shady private repos.
  • Stay curious and skeptical. That mix saved me this time.

üòÇ Final Thought‚Äã

I don‚Äôt have a crypto wallet ‚Äî and I‚Äôm not planning to get one.
So please, don‚Äôt send me any blockchain ‚Äújob offers.‚Äù
My chain is already full. üòÖ

Stay safe, developers.
Sometimes, the biggest red flag isn‚Äôt in the code ‚Äî it‚Äôs in the offer that looks too good to be true.

item.title: I Bought a Raspberry Pi 5 ‚Äì And Almost Regretted It
item.description: I bought a Raspberry Pi 5 ‚Äì And Almost Regretted It
item.content:encoded:
I recently ordered a Raspberry Pi 5 from Temu, along with a microSD card, card reader, and micro HDMI cable, all for around $110. However, I made one big mistake‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt buy a power supply.

I thought it would be fun for my kids to see the naked circuit board, so I skipped buying a case. But I completely overlooked the fact that the Raspberry Pi 5 requires a USB-C power adapter capable of 5V/5A.

The Search for Power‚Äã

When my package arrived, I was excited‚Äîuntil I realized I had no way to power it. I searched my home and checked nearby stores, but the best I could find were standard USB adapters rated at 2.4A‚Äì3A. Even my EcoFlow power station couldn‚Äôt provide the required amperage.

Then, a lightbulb moment. Car USB chargers usually have higher amperage! Since my EcoFlow has a car plug, I wondered if I could use a car USB adapter to power the Raspberry Pi. I asked ChatGPT whether EcoFlow could provide 5A through the car port, and it said yes. That gave me hope.

I ran to my car and checked my USB converter, only to find it was rated at just 3A. Still, I didn‚Äôt give up. I rushed to a store that sells car accessories and found a 6A AC adapter on the shelf. On my way home, I kept wondering‚Äîcan this really provide 5V/5A? I have very little knowledge about electricity. All I know is:

Voltage √ó Amperage = Wattage

That‚Äôs it.

Heartbreak & Frustration‚Äã

Back home, I eagerly plugged everything in‚Äîbut my Raspberry Pi didn‚Äôt start. I had no idea if the issue was with the EcoFlow or the car plug. It was a frustrating moment.

I‚Äôve worked with Raspberry Pi before, back in my previous company. I experimented with it, set it up as a DHCP server, connected it to CCTV cameras via LAN, and even used FFmpeg for car plate recognition with machine learning. But somehow, I overlooked those two tiny letters‚Äî5A.

Now, I was stuck waiting for another power adapter to arrive from somewhere in China. I had planned to surprise my kids by showing them their very own computer, but now it seemed like that plan was ruined.

The Unexpected Solution‚Äã

As a last attempt, I carefully read every warning message on the screen. One of them caught my eye:

Click the power button for low-power mode.

Wait‚Ä¶ WHAT?!

This message was there all along? Seriously?!

I clicked the power button, and boom‚ÄîRaspberry Pi OS booted up! My screen lit up, and so did my heart.

Of course, running in low-power mode meant it wouldn‚Äôt perform at full potential. But it was enough for some basic exploration, web browsing, and even listening to YouTube music through a Bluetooth speaker.

A Small but Meaningful Victory‚Äã

It wasn‚Äôt the perfect experience, but in the end, I made it work‚Äîand that was the little victory I needed.
